repnme.cdata!:
How does geographic distance affect credit
            market access in Niger ?

abstracts.cdata!:
Distances involved in accessing basic
            services can constitute a major barrier to development. This
            paper analyzes the relationship between the distance
            separating households from microfinance institutions'
            offices in Niger, and the low levels of development and
            performance of the microfinance sector in the country. To
            cope with the effects of geographical distance, microfinance
            institutions adapt their policies through more restrictive
            loan conditions, higher interest rates, and more intensive
            screening. The authors to discuss the tension between access
            and sustainability in the context of financial services for
            the poor.

repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Second Public Expenditure
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey a satisfactory project
            outcome, likely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts. Recommendations rather than lessons are
            provided, first indicating that not only did the Public
            Expenditure Management and Financial Accountability Review
            (PEMFAR) report develop a more comprehensive diagnosis, and
            more detailed recommendations - including a more realistic
            sequencing of the proposed public finance reforms - but it
            helped all stakeholders better understand the rationale for
            the reforms, as more emphasis was placed on deepening the
            reform process, on improving the structure of public
            expenditures and on modernizing the country's budget
            planning, and management instruments. The PEMFAR became
            critical to the success of the project. Moreover, the type
            of technical support national institutions need to implement
            reforms, is not just through the Bank (which should not be
            the sole institution involved in the preparation and
            financing of such program), but also the country itself
            should develop a budget reform/poverty reduction-related,
            capacity-building strategy, that should be discussed with,
            and supported by, all major donors. Finally, the protection
            of activities and expenditures, vital to improve the
            performance of public sector institutions and support the
            goal of poverty reduction, require projections of government
            revenue, based on a realistic external support:
            overoptimistic budget assumptions about available resources,
            will render impossible to adequately attain high-priority
            maintenance and operating expenditures; rather, annual
            budget preparation should be initiated at the earliest
            possible stage, preferably during preparation of sector
            strategies and medium-term public expenditure frameworks.
            The study of the protection of vital recurrent expenditures
            should also address the seasonality of both spending, and
            available resources. Finally, it is suggested that sector
            specialists need to be heavily involved in the design, and
            supervision of a multi-sector adjustment program, focusing
            on budget reform. Linking adjustment credits and sectoral
            programs probably is the best way to give Bank sector
            specialists the incentive to monitor effectively the
            progress of the reforms to be implemented in their sector.

repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Second Public Expenditure
            Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Public Expenditure Adjustment
            Credit Project for Niger is designed to help implement the
            Government's economic reform program during 2003-2004
            and Niger's January 2002 Poverty Reduction Strategy
            Paper (PRSP) by supporting key policy measures aiming at:
            (i) consolidating sound macroeconomic and financial
            policies; (ii) strengthening the public expenditure
            management reform program; and (iii) supporting the ongoing
            implementation of key social and structural reforms. The
            proposed operation is expected to help the implementation of
            the poverty reduction program by: (i) fostering
            macroeconomic and financial stability; (ii) improving
            budgeting and public expenditure management and basic
            service delivery (health, education, and water services);
            and (iii) improving the environment conducive to
            private-sector development. Four main risks could influence
            the expected outcomes of the proposed credit: (i) domestic
            political unrest and or external factors, including a
            shortfall in donor support, adverse climatic conditions, and
            social and political upheavals in neighboring countries;
            (ii) weak institutional, managerial and administrative
            capacity; (iii) slippages in key reforms; and (iv) growth
            and macroeconomic scenarios may not materialize. These risks
            are mitigated by the strength of the Government's
            ownership and commitment to implement the proposed measures,
            by an active policy dialogue between the Bank and the
            Government, and by donor's efforts to provide technical
            assistance to improve capacity-building , The project will
            be released in two tranches.
